instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
Hey everybody I've got a motherboard A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> but it's kinda messy.

[B]HISTORY :[/B]
The customer brought it saying that it suddenly won't turn on. He said that the laptop was always and only serviced by Apple Store. It appears that they already replaced the screen and the motherboard :LOL:))))

When I opened it I was shocked : several screws were missing and others were all over the board. One screw was stuck between pin 1 and 2 of the <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8036</CAPACITOR> was destroyed !! (pics attached)

[B]MEASUREMENTS :[/B]
I pulled the board out and replaced <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C8036</CAPACITOR> and was getting 20V and the apms were getting up to 0.70 and resetting to 0.05, basically looping.

I started to do some measurement around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CAPACITOR>C7078</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>) and suddenly (I might have short-circuited smth) i'm getting only 5V at 0.05A

Other measurement I did

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_LDO5V</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> - 0v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0v 

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> - 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.79V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL> - 1.79V

<CAPACITOR>C7078</CAPACITOR> - 5V
<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> - pin1 - 0V, pin2 - 5V, pin3 - 5;V

Thank you for all your support

Best regards

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
Start checking diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; be sure F7000 is good.
Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>. VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>; <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
thank for your reply )

[I]F7000 [/I]- is good
[I]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>[/I] - 0.45
[I]<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>[/I] :
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> - 1.28V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - 0V
VDDA/P - 0.38V
<SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL> - 0.29V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL> - 0.1V
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> - 0V
A/BMON - 0.28 on both

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
"VDDA/P - 0.38V"
Check diode mode to ground on both.
If good, change <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
Great I've got back the 20V after replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

So now I have steady 20V, fan spins ones and amps go to 0.6 and back to 0.05A

So basically looping as before I short-circuited the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
Do you get stable <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage?

Check if voltage appears on big coils each time fan spins.

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
it goes like this 

when plugged, voltage goes to 3.6V
when fan starts to spin, goes up 13V
after back to 3.7V, then 4V, then 0V and back to 13V

and fan does spin any more.

Tested on F7000 pin2

threads.message:

Can you check ALL big coils for voltage pulse (at least), when fan spins???

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05

Tried on both ports : it goes till 0.60-0.65A and back to 0.05A and steady 20V

fan spins only once and rapidly stops

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
Probably bad CPU.
Power on sequence seems to completes, if you get VCORE pulse.
So there must be communication problem.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?
Just in case, check for short and voltage pulse on all outputs from page 64.
Also check L7930.

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
yep also pulsating

<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> - 1.29V
L7930 - 1.79V

on page 64 I have [B]4x mono speaker amplifier[/B], is that it ?)

I'm using <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (ZEON) Schematic diagram

threads.title: A-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Stuck at 5V 0.05
threads.message:
I have X502/MLB CATZ schematic.
Page 64 is about Power FETs, in my case.
